moduleSubtitle: Dental, respiratory, dermatologic, sun, and poison care

content.content: BROKEN TOOTH
A broken tooth may chip, crack or fracture and is usually a problem if the nerve is exposed to air. Exposed nerve causes sensitivity or pain to air, cold/hot foods, and drinks.
Tx

If tooth pulp is exposed, apply a small piece of crushed aspirin to cauterize the nerve (burning sensation followed by relief). Consider oral analgesics and/or apply oil of cloves to the gum surrounding the damaged tooth for pain. Evacuate any trip participant with exposed pulp to a dentist within 48 hours. Note: aspirin is acidic and should never be placed on the gum of an aching tooth.
LOST FILLING OR CROWN
Partial or entire fillings that have fallen out or a crown that has dislodged expose the nerve and cause sensitivity to air, cold/hot foods and drinks.
Tx

Brush teeth and rinse with disinfected water. Dry the area with sterile gauze and fill hole or secure crown with Cavit®, wax, or sugarless gum. Consider oral analgesics and/or oil of cloves for pain. Evacuate to a dentist within 48 hours.
TOOTH ABSCESS
Infection in the gum line caused by trapped food, untreated decay, gum disease, recent root canal, or trauma.
Pain while chewing, swelling along the gum line, and/or a pus-filled pimple on the gum adjacent to the infected tooth.
Tx

Brush and floss to remove trapped food, rinse mouth with salty water several times a day. If abscess is visible consider lancing with a sterile blade or needle to drain pus, rinse with disinfected water, and consider antibiotics per protocol. Evacuate to definitive care ASAP.
AVULSED TOOTH
A tooth partially or completely dislodged from its socket with bleeding and pain.
Tx

Irrigate tooth; do not scrub or touch the root. Attempt to replace in its socket and splint with Cavit®, wax, or sugarless gum. If not possible, wrap in sterile gauze and place between cheek and gum or in Save-a-Tooth®/water. Consider analgesics and/or oil of cloves. Evacuate to an oral surgeon immediately; reimplantation success drops after 30–60 minutes.
Mixed signals between the eyes and inner ear trigger nausea, dizziness, pale skin, and fatigue.
Prevention: sit forward facing, focus on the horizon, use transdermal scopolamine or OTC antiemetics (Benadryl®, Dramamine®, Bonine®, Gravol®). Sea Band® acupressure on pericardium 6 can help.
Tx
Remove the person from the motion stimulus. Ginger products or OTC antihistamines can relieve nausea (watch for drowsiness). Persistent vomiting may require prescription antiemetics or IV therapy.
COMMON COLD
Viral upper respiratory infection (typically rhinovirus) resolving in 7–10 days with runny nose, cough, sore throat, aches, fatigue, chills, and occasional fever.
Tx
Rest, fluids, analgesics, decongestants/antihistamines. Emphasize hand washing and hygiene.
SORE THROAT
Inflammation from dry/cold air or infection (viral, occasionally strep) with throat pain, difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, swollen tonsils.
Hydrate, warm salt gargle, rest, analgesics. ⚠ Evacuate if unable to swallow or throat is red, swollen, and coated with white spots.
INFLUENZA
Viral infection with respiratory and systemic symptoms lasting up to two weeks.
Supportive care (fluids, rest, analgesics, decongestants). Isolate the patient. ⚠ Evacuate if fever >102°F (39°C) persists >2 days or signs of pneumonia develop.
FEVER
Symptom of underlying illness with chills, shivering, muscle aches, lethargy, headache, and malaise.
Antipyretics (ibuprofen, acetaminophen) for comfort; most fevers self-limit. ⚠ Evacuate if fever >102°F (39°C) lasts more than two days or illness worsens.
HEADACHE
Non-specific symptom often caused by dehydration, hyponatremia, AMS, heat exhaustion, or medical conditions.
Hydrate, use analgesics, treat contributing factors. ⚠ Evacuate sudden severe headaches or those unresponsive to treatment and associated with stiff neck or inability to ambulate.
COVID-19
Coronavirus disease with cough, fever/chills, dyspnea, aches, sore throat, anosmia, GI symptoms, congestion, fatigue, headache, nausea/vomiting.
Treat supportively and quarantine. Use PPE for caregivers. Evacuate symptomatic patients, especially elderly or immunocompromised.
OUTER EAR INFECTION (OTITIS EXTERNA)
Moisture-driven bacterial or fungal infection (swimmer’s ear). Prevention: shake out water and rinse canal with diluted vinegar.
Pain/pressure worsened by pushing on the tragus or pulling on the lobe.
Treat with a 1:1 mixture of rubbing alcohol and vinegar to dry and re-acidify the canal; avoid water until resolved.
OBJECTS IN THE EAR/EYE
Small objects or insects may lodge in the ear canal; dirt and debris often hide under the eyelid.
Irrigate the ear canal with clean water or remove visible objects with tweezers. For eye debris remove contacts and flush copiously; leave impaled objects and evacuate.
NOSE BLEED (EPISTAXIS)
Usually benign and common at altitude with dry, cool air, presenting as spontaneous bleeding from one nostril.
Pinch the bridge below the cartilage, lean forward, spit blood. Pack the nostril and evacuate if bleeding cannot be controlled.
POISON IVY, OAK & SUMAC
Urushiol-induced contact dermatitis with extremely itchy, red rash and fluid-filled blisters. Inhalation of burning plants can trigger anaphylaxis.
Prevention: identify the plants, wear protective clothing, and wash clothing/gear with detergent or Tecnu®.
Wash exposed skin immediately with cold water and soap. Consider Tecnu Extreme®, antihistamines, or oral steroids. ⚠ Evacuate anyone with inhalation exposure or breathing difficulty.
FUNGAL INFECTIONS
Typically grow in dark, warm, moist areas like feet and groin; prevent with breathable fabrics and frequent clothing changes.
Red, swollen, itchy, scaling or cracking skin.
Clean and air-dry the affected area, allow the skin to breathe, apply diluted tea tree oil, 1% hydrocortisone, or OTC antifungal creams.
SUNBURN
Reddening of skin due to prolonged ultraviolet exposure with hot, swollen, painful skin, chills, fatigue, and possible blisters.
Prevention: protective UPF clothing and SPF ≥15 sunscreen reapplied during the day.
Treat with aloe vera gel, hydration, and avoidance of further sun until healed.
SNOW BLINDNESS
UV burn on the surface of the eye common at altitude or near reflective surfaces; presents with red, teary, painful, light-sensitive eyes.
Prevention: high-quality sunglasses/glacier goggles or improvised slit eyewear.
Remove contacts, keep eyes closed, apply cool wet compresses, consider analgesics. Symptoms usually resolve within 48 hours; avoid sun until clear.
FISH HOOKS
Attach dental floss around the hook belly, depress the shank, and snap the string to remove. Clean the wound.
SPLINTERS
Press toward the exit, grasp the exposed end with tweezers, or lift skin with a sterilized needle to access deeper splinters.
BLISTERS
Fluid-filled pockets from friction. Prevention: cover hotspots, change wet socks, use liners, and break in boots.
Clean the area, lance with a sterile needle, leave the roof intact, apply 2nd Skin® and secure with tincture of benzoin and tape.
Poisons can be ingested, absorbed, inhaled, or injected.
Prevention: ventilate shelters, avoid cooking in poorly ventilated spaces, clearly label fuel and corrosive liquids.
Tx

Do not induce vomiting. Consult poison control if available. Remove the patient from inhaled poisons and administer oxygen if possible. See other sections for injected (bites/stings) or absorbed (urushiol) toxins.
